conclusion: Analyze refraction of light through wedge-shaped glass to determine ratio of light-emitting part length to edge length.
Wedge has a top angle of 30 degrees; light source S emits light perpendicular to side OP; refraction angle is 45 degrees.
Snell's Law: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2), where n1 and n2 are refractive indices, theta1 and theta2 are angles of incidence and refraction.
Angle of incidence theta1 is 0 degrees; angle of refraction theta2 is 45 degrees.
Light enters glass without bending initially as it is perpendicular to the surface.
Inside the glass, light refracts at 45 degrees relative to the normal N.
Light travels through glass and exits through edge OQ; angle between refracted light and edge OQ is 45 degrees.
Using trigonometry, length of light-emitting part on edge can be calculated using sine of angle between refracted light and edge.
Total length of edge OQ is hypotenuse of right triangle formed by refracted light path; length of light-emitting part is opposite side of angle 45 degrees.
Ratio of length of light-emitting part to length of edge is given by sine of angle 45 degrees.
